events.message: This community NEEDS to adopt a code of conduct. Recent events make this glaringly obvious.

events.body: Let me know if you'd like me to squash.

I want to be clear here. I am a staunch supporter of free speech and have previously been opposed to such things. My mind has been changed, not just by this project, by watching friends and talented engineers berated, harassed, and generally have their mental health destroyed.

I'm unsure as to whether the current contact language is appropriate as I agree with said policy that anonymity preservation should be an option when reporting.

Input?

issue.title: This community NEEDS to adopt a code of conduct. Recent events make t…

events.body:
Who is going to be responsible for governing this policy? 

Will this open us up to the possibility of having a  "man in the high castle" scenario, where one person dictates what is offensive based on their own personal feelings? 

Also, if that happens, will there be any arbitration procedures for those falsely accused of harassment, or perhaps even those who were just taken the wrong way when putting forth their thoughts on any given topic? 

I guess what I'm trying to say is, who will watch the watchers?
I leave those questions to the maintainers themselves. This is becoming a widely accepted policy amongst respectable open source projects and I'm tiring of watching the decline of this one.
This one being "bitcoin software in general," to be clear, I'm making no accusations and @sipa is a very congenial and helpful person in specific.

You already tried pulling this nonsense into libbitcoin, https://github.com/libbitcoin/libbitcoin/pull/355 , which was wholly rejected there. 

It seems to me that you are trying to address a problem that doesn't exist.

issue.title: This community NEEDS to adopt a code of conduct. Recent events make t…

events.body:
I haven't yet read this, but if the goal here is to have a CoC for libsecp256k1, I think the PR should say that (rather than "this project"). If you mean the Bitcoin community in general should be less toxic, sure, but I don't think this project is the place to start that.

In general, interactions within libsecp256k1 seem to me to be polite and technical. This is maybe the nicest place you can find within the Bitcoin community.

So while I might sign onto a CoC (though again, I haven't yet taken the time to read this one) I'm unsure one is really needed in this case.

Having said all this, please do not turn this PR, or any PR, into a personal fight. @jrmithdobbs's conduct here or elsewhere is not relevant in my mind to the merits of this pull request.

They do indeed and again I do not wish to imply otherwise. It is my feeling that declaring these things up front to explicitly state intent is more welcoming. That is all there is to this. Hats off to you guys, you do fantastic work.
*indeed seem to be congenial I meant. That is why I specifically called out @sipa's awesomeness as an example when I realized I had stated that poorly.

Thank you for your concern @unclediazepam. I have seen this happen in other projects, and I do consider this risk quite serious, as well as the risk that we develop or invite a "language police" culture.

As I mentioned in my earlier post, I believe that the people working on libsecp256k1 already provide a welcoming and polite environment, though I'm willing to be convinced otherwise. In particular, I think the contributors here who have **not** suffered adverse mental health effects from the caustic environment in the wider Bitcoin community (aside from those who ignore it entirely) are a minority. So I trust the current maintainers to uphold the current level of conduct, if only for their own sake.

So with those thoughts I'm going to leave this PR alone for a while, and perhaps a maintainer with a more strongly-felt stance will step in.
I just want to link this here: https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/7243#issuecomment-166467231
Thanks for your kind words, but we'll deal with this problem when it appears.
